A talk on Mississippi's history of racial injustice with ACLU Deputy Legal director Jeff Robinson.

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

Given the current climate of racial division in Mississippi, it's more important than ever that we take a hard look at our state's history of racial violence and discrimination.

We're in a critical moment where we must confront our past head-on so that we can pave a new path forward for Mississippi.

That's why on Monday, November 19, we'll be joined by ACLU Deputy Legal Director Jeff Robinson for A Front Row Seat: An ACLU Conversation on Racism in Mississippi and America.

A Front Row Seat will offer insight into the state's history of slavery, slave patrols, lynchings, black codes, Jim Crow, and modern-day mass incarceration.

A Front Row Seat:
An ACLU Conversation on Racism in Mississippi and America

A talk about Mississippi's history of racial injustice and what comes next for us.

Monday, November 19, 5:30 p.m.
Jackson Convention Complex
105 E Pascagoula St.
Jackson, MS 39201

RSVP TODAY

Mississippi was a key state where the civil rights movement unfolded because of our long history of racial segregation, discrimination, and violence.

By learning from our past, not only can we recognize the systems in our state that uphold racial injustice, but we can take the action necessary to move us forward.

We hope you'll join us this Monday evening for the reception at 5:30 p.m. followed by a reflective look at Mississippi's history.

Jennifer Riley-Collins
Executive Director, ACLU of Mississippi
